bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 27, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg informs Kean of the difficulties of balancing historical accuracy against the requirements of artistic composition in the painting “Conquerors of Yellow Fever.” [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 27, 1941
div1.opener:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
March 27, 1941.
General Jefferson R. Kean
2804 “N” Street, N.W.
Georgetown, Washington, D.C.
Dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I wish to thank you for your kind letter of March 22nd which has been
read with great interest.

Mr. Cornwall and I have gone over all the correspondence and have
spent several hours discussing the varied points of view which have
been brought up. With all the information that has been supplied
us by yourself and others we at least have the satisfaction of
knowing whether or not what we are doing is historically accurate.
If we do paint a picture which in all details is not historically
accurate we will know so in advance and not be embarrassed by having
the point brought up after the picture is completed. It seems to
be impossible to work up a composition which will give the casual
observer a more or less all around grasp of the subject we are trying
to memorialize and at the same time be historically accurate in all
details. There is also the constant clash between what Mr. Cornwall
thinks is artistically good and what is historically accurate.
Within the next few days we must come to a decision and I can see
right now that we will not please anyone thoroughly. In the last
analysis I have to let Mr. Cornwall decide what will produce a fine
painting from the standpoint of an artist and in so doing I have to
compromise all down the line on historical accuracy. The painting
will be a composite and not a picture of any one actual event. I
hope that you and all our other kind advisors will forgive our not
following out all your suggestions. Merely because they have not been
used is no indication that they have not been much appreciated.

I am having the copy of your address on the dedication of the Walter
Reed birthplace photostated for my files and am enclosing a copy of
the photostat along with the original in this letter. I enjoyed
reading this and completed it with an increased comprehension of the
importance of what we are attempting to do.
My kindest regards to Mrs. Kean and yourself.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George A. Kellogg George A. Kellogg
ecs
Encl.
P.S. I find that the reprint
and photostat will not be
ready until tomorrow.
